STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 12, 2023
Tracey Compton
UPPER PENINSULA FAMILY SOLUTIONS
369 US HIGHWAY 41 E,
NEGAUNEE, MI, 49866-9624
Re: License #: CB520304693
Dear Ms. Compton:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
May 1, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Linda Tansil, Area Manager, at 734-775-8293.
Sincerely,
Douglas Turrill, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
2

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program
statement to a youth before placement in
independent living.
One of one independent living files did not document that the youth received a copy
of the program statement.
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent
living with a copy of the agency’s policies and
procedures required by this rule.
One of one independent living files did not document that the youth received a copy
of the agency’s policies and procedures.
CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements
2

(1) An agency shall document the rationale for
selection of independent living as the most
appropriate placement for the youth.
One of one independent living files did not document rationale for selection of
independent living as the most appropriate placement for the youth.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living contract
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract
between the youth and the agency specifying all of
the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the
youth.
One of one independent living files did not contain an independent living contract
signed by the youth.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
0 4/01/2022 Renewal - CAP approved 04/25/2022.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Second line supervisor,
when siblings in care are placed apart. • Parents who
are a member of a participating household. • Youth
ages 14 and older. • Foster parents, relative
caregivers, and unrelated court ordered caregivers.
Six foster care files and 19 service plans were reviewed. Five of 19 services plans
documented late signatures. A PATP dated November 18, 2022, was signed by the
foster parent on December 20, 2022. A PATP dated February 16, 2023, was signed
by the parent on March 22, 2023. A PATP dated November 18, 2022, was signed by
the youth on January 9, 2023. A PATP dated August 20, 2022, was signed by the
foster parent on January 9, 2023, and by the parent on December 20, 2022. A
3

PATP dated December 11, 2022, was signed by the foster parent on January 31,
2023.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
04/01/2022 Renewal - CAP approved 04/25/2022.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date. Note: This FTM may be combined with
the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM. Updated Case Plan
(USP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date. Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) -
within 30 calendar days before the case plan due
date.
At least three business days prior to a planned
change of placement or no later than three business
days after an unplanned placement change. Planned
and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting,
stepdown from a residential or hospital setting,
return from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
home/relative placements.
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is used
to capture family demographics, FTM logistical
information, needs, strengths, action steps, safety
concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the
FTM. The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report,
must be completed for every FTM.
Seventeen FTM’s were viewed. One of seventeen was completed more than 30
days from the date of the March 19, 2023, USP due date. The FTM was held on
February 14, 2023.
FTM’s were not completed for placement changes that occurred on August 30,
2022, and March 21, 2023.
One of 17 FTM’s did not document a DHHS-1005 for the meeting held on March 9,
2023.
4

REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
04/01/2022 Renewal - CAP approved 04/25/2022.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to
reflect the child's current and complete health
information. n updated medical passport is provided
to: • Participating legal parents if the child is a
temporary court ward. Quarterly, while in out-of-
home placement. At reunification. Subsequent
medical passports are not required after
reunification. Non-offending parent, subsequent
medical passports are not required after
reunification.
One of six files had a gap where the medical passport was not updated. The gap
period was from May 12, 2022. to October 28, 2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following area:
Technical assistance was provided regarding youth with YAFC status who are
placed in an independent living placement. Discussion involved YAFC youth,
when in an independent living arrangement such as a college dorm or an
apartment, then that youth is considered to be in independent living and the
independent living rules apply. The independent living rules do not apply to
YAFC youth living with a relative, in a foster home or a CCI.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Consultation was not requested or offered at this time.
5

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The
current Interim Inspection established three repeat violations. They are as follows:
FOM 722-06B, Fom 722-08D and R 400.12510. The CAP was sucessful in
preventing the other violations established during the 2022 Renewal Inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrators assessment was thorough and addressed the agency
renewal inspection corrective action plan. The assessment also addressed
systemic barriers such as the lack of dental providers in the area as well as the
large geographical area the agency covers in providing services. The assessment
noted that the agency provides quality services beyond what is required of the
rules and policy. The complexity of the foster care cases also presents challenges
to providing for the needs of children and families.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted an annual budget and the agency is financially viable. A
review of an annual certified public accountant audit was conducted.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported that they feel supported by the agency supervisors and
administration. Staff report that supervisors are knowledgeable and are there for
support when needed. Staff also reported that the team works together in
supporting each other. Two staff reported that the new CWIS system is difficult
and time consuming to work with.
Youth were not interviewed by the Consultant.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency has sufficient office space and is well organized and equipped.
6

VII. CPA ANALYST FINDINGS
The CPA Analyst identified two safety alerts during her visits to the homes. They are
as follows;
Safety Alert #1. On January 24, 2023, a safety alert was sent to the agency
indicating there was no smoke alarm on the top level of the home. A complaint was
filed and the agency initiated special evaluation #2023C0000291. Resolution was
obtained on January 25, 2023, as a smoke alarm was installed and a photo of the
installed alarm was provided.
Safety Alert #2. On January 24, 2023, a safety alert was generated as a carbon
monoxide detector was missing a battery and there was firearm ammunition that
was not locked. Late in the afternoon of January 24, 2023, photos were provided
showing the ammunition box had a lock installed and a battery was installed into the
carbon monoxide detector. Safety alert resolved.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
May 12, 2023
________________________________________
Douglas W Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
